III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following: (b) Health
screening procedures.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
1

Allegation A youth that was at the facility from September 2007 to July 2008
reported that they were diagnosed with psychosis while at the
facility when they had autism.
Investigation Interviews
Complainant was contacted by email on 04/25/2025 and
responded on 04/28/2025. Complainant did not have additional
information.
Former Youth (FY) was not interviewed. Telephone numbers
found in MiSACWIS for FY are either no longer in service or
reissued to someone else.
Consumer Rights Officer (CRO) was interviewed on 04/24/2025
at Vista Maria. CRO stated most of FY’s service plans were
discarded in accordance with Child Caring Institutions licensing
rules.
Documentation
FY was placed at Vista Maria on 09/20/2007 and discharged on
07/31/2008. FY’s available service plans were reviewed.
• Initial Service Plan dated 09/20/2007 to 10/20/2007 lists
bipolar disorder in FY’s Axis I diagnosis along with ruling
out psychosis.
• Updated Service Plan dated 01/18/2008 to 04/18/2008 and
Updated Service Plan dated 04/18/2028 to 07/18/2008 lists
bipolar disorder in FY’s Axis I diagnosis and ruling out
psychosis. It also includes Pervasive Development
Disorder.
This allegation was reviewed using current Licensing Rules for
Child Caring Institutions with an effective date of 12/05/2019.
Resident records shall be maintained for not less than 7 years
after the resident is discharged per R 400.4167 Case record
maintenance.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance because FY’s available service
plans show she was diagnosed with Pervasive Development
Disorder (which is a former term used for autism spectrum
disorder) and psychosis was being ruled out.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & R 400.4162 Seclusion within secure and nonsecure facilities;
Section seclusion plan; prohibitions; reduction and elimination.
Description (5) Staff may not use seclusion for discipline, punishment,
administrative convenience, retaliation, staffing shortages, or
2

reasons other than a temporary response to behavior that
threatens immediate harm to a youth or others.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A youth that was at the facility from September 2007 to July 2008
reported that if the youth would not take their medications, they
would be locked in a room or forcibly injected.
Investigation Interviews
Complainant was contacted by email on 04/25/2025 and
responded on 04/28/2025. Complainant did not have additional
information.
Former Youth (FY) was not interviewed. Telephone numbers
found in MiSACWIS for FY are either no longer in service or
reissued to someone else.
Consumer Rights Officer (CRO) was interviewed on 04/24/2025
at Vista Maria. CRO stated most of FY’s medical documentation
was destroyed per Health Insurance Portability and Accountability
Act and FY’s incident reports were discarded in accordance with
Child Caring Institutions licensing rules.
Documentation
FY’s available service plans (initial service plan 09/20/2007 to
10/20/2007 and updated service plans 01/18/2008 to 04/18/2008
and 04/18/2008 to 07/18/2008) reviewed do not document FY’s
incidents of seclusion or medication by injection.
Division of Child Welfare Licensing does not keep a record of
investigative reports dating back to 2007 and 2008.
This allegation was reviewed using current Licensing Rules for
Child Caring Institutions with an effective date of 12/05/2019.
Resident records shall be maintained for not less than 7 years
after the resident is discharged per R 400.4167 Case record
maintenance.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance based on the lack of
information to determine if improper use of seclusion and improper
medication by injection occurred at Vista Maria in 2007 and 2008.
It is unknown if this allegation was reported or investigated in 2007
and 2008.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
3

Rule Code & R 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth’s behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth’s
treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A youth that was at the facility from September 2007 to July 2008
reported improper restraints took place to include being held down
with staff's knees on the youth's neck and back while the youth
was screaming that they could not breathe.
Investigation Interviews
Complainant was contacted by email on 04/25/2025 and
responded on 04/28/2025. Complainant did not have additional
information.
Former Youth (FY) was not interviewed. Telephone numbers

reissued to someone else. A youth that was at the facility from
September 2007 to July 2008 reported improper restraints took
place to include being held down with staff's knees on the youth's
neck and back while the youth was screaming that they could not
breathe.
Consumer Rights Officer (CRO) was interviewed on 04/24/2025
at Vista Maria. CRO stated FY’s incident reports were discarded in
accordance with Child Caring Institutions licensing rules.
Documentation
FY’s available service plans (initial service plan 09/20/2007 to
10/20/2007 and updated service plans 01/18/2008 to 04/18/2008
and 04/18/2008 to 07/18/2008) do not document FY’s restraint
incidents. FY’s initial service plan states Nonviolent Crisis Physical
Intervention may be used if FY is a danger to self or others.
Division of Child Welfare Licensing does not keep a record of
investigative reports dating back to 2007 and 2008.
This allegation was reviewed using the amended R 400.4159 of
the Michigan Administrative Code with an effective date of
05/31/2022. It is noted that in 2007 and 2008 prone restraints
were permitted. This allegation was also reviewed using current
4

Licensing Rules for Child Caring Institutions with an effective of
12/05/2019. Resident records shall be maintained for not less than
7 years after the resident is discharged per R 400.4167 Case
record maintenance.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance based on the lack of
information to determine if improper restraints occurred at Vista
Maria in 2007 and 2008. It is unknown if this allegation was
reported or investigated in 2007 and 2008.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following: (c)
Documentation of medical care and maintenance of health care
records.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A youth that was at the facility from September 2007 to July 2008
reported there were multiple incidents of self-harm and suicide
attempts with little or no medical follow-up.
Investigation Interviews
Complainant was contacted by email on 04/25/2025 and
responded on 04/28/2025. Complainant did not have additional
information.
Former Youth (FY) was not interviewed. Telephone numbers
found in MiSACWIS for FY are either no longer in service or
reissued to someone else.
Consumer Rights Officer (CRO) was interviewed on 04/24/2025
at Vista Maria. CRO stated most of FY’s medical documentation
was destroyed per Health Insurance Portability and Accountability
Act and FY’s incident reports were discarded in accordance with
Child Caring Institutions licensing rules.
Therapist, who wrote Youth A’s available service plans, was not
interviewed. Therapist is no longer employed at Vista Maria and
her current telephone number is unavailable.
Documentation
FY’s available service plans do not contain documentation about
FY’s self-harm or suicide attempts but the following was noted.
• FY’s initial service dated 09/20/2007 to 10/2007 states FY
was placed on 15-minute observation for precautionary
measures due to threat to self and others. It states FY had
5

difficulty transitioning to Vista Maria program milieu
displayed through verbal aggression and explosive
outbursts towards the teacher and youths.
• FY’s updated service plan dated 01/18/2008 to 04/18/2008
states FY’s 15-minute observation status decreased with
the improvement of FY’s emotional stability through her use
of coping strategies.
• FY’s updated service plan dated 04/18/2008 to 07/18/2008
states FY continued to decrease her verbal aggression and
demonstrated positive use of coping skills. It states FY was
stable and productive at school and on the unit.
01/23/2008 Progress note states FY slammed her right hand in
the wall and complained of pain. An appointment on 01/25/2008
was scheduled for FY. There is no available documentation on the
status of the 01/25/2008 appointment.
01/31/2008 Hospital radiology report states FY had bruising and
swelling on her fourth knuckle on her right hand, but no evidence
of dislocation or fracture.
02/05/2008 Progress note states FY intentionally hit her head
three times on the metal doorknob in the behavior management
room. FY did not complain of headache, nausea or blurred vision.
FY observed without swelling, abrasion or laceration to the head.
FY was released from behavior management room.
Division of Child Welfare Licensing does not keep a record of
investigative reports dating back to 2007 and 2008.
This allegation was reviewed using current Licensing Rules for
Child Caring Institutions with an effective date of 12/05/2019.
Resident records shall be maintained for not less than 7 years
after the resident is discharged per R 400.4167 Case record
maintenance.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance based on the inability to
completely review FY’s health records and incident reports along
with interviews to determine if there was a lack of response in
incidents of self-harm or suicide attempts. It is unknown if this
allegation was reported or investigated in 2007 and 2008.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
6

perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.

Rule Code & R 400.4112 Criminal history check subject to requirements;
Section staff qualifications.
Description (1) Child caring institutions subject to 42 USC 671 shall not permit
a child caring institution staff member to begin working unless all

Rule Code & R 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following: (c)
Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety and
supervision methods for addressing residents’ needs,

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type

8

Division of Child Welfare Licensing does not keep a record of

Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.

sir_summary.summary: A special investigation was conducted into allegations made by a former youth at Vista Maria from 2007-2008, covering misdiagnosis, improper seclusion and medication, dangerous restraints, inadequate medical follow-up for self-harm, staff instigating fights, improper background checks, and dismissal of sexual misconduct. The investigation found no established violations for any allegation due to insufficient records and inability to interview key parties, concluding the facility is in compliance. However, the inability to substantiate the serious claims stems primarily from record destruction and witness unavailability, not from a definitive finding of proper past conduct.
